The <section> tag is used to DIVIDE a module into pieces, as its name suggests.

ul.li: name is a required attribute. It contains the name of the section.
A unique id attribute is required.

body.pre: <para id='para1'> There are three ideal circuit elements. They are the resistor, capacitor, and the inductor. </para> <section name='Resistor' id='res'> <para id='para2'> Here is some information about the resistor. </para> </section> <section name='Capacitor' id='cap'> <para id='para3'> Here is some information about the capacitor. </para> </section> <section name='inductor' id='ind'> <para id='para4'> Here is some informatino about the inductor. <para> </section>
body.p: <section> can contain one or more section, cnxn, link, important, emphasis, math, para, equation, list, code, figure, table, example, or exercise.
A <para> contains a paragraph of text.

ul.li: It has a required id attribute.

body.pre: <para id='para1'> Prince Andrei was on duty that day and in constant attendance on the Commander in Chief. </para> <para id='para2'> At six o'clock in the evening Kutuzov went to the Enperor's headquarters, and after remaining but a short time with him, went to the Grand Marshal of the Court, Count Tolstoy. </para>
body.p: A paragraph must contain at least one of emphasis, important, list, cnxn, link, equation, math or plain text.

A <figure> contains the structure for creating a figure within a document. A figure could contain such things as an image, or a table, or several of these. The stylesheet could be set up so that the figure could be referenced elsewhere in the document.

ul.li: Has a required id attribute.
It has an optional name attribute. This should be used to give a description of the figure that would help a search engine find it.

There is a required orient attribute. This attribute can be set to horizontal or vertical. This attribute is used when there are subfigures. It allows the writer to determine which way subfigures should line up. That is, if there is an important reason why a series of subfigures should places next to each other then this attribute is set to horizontal, and if they should be on top of each other then it is set to vertical.

p.font: Figure 1 The cat displayed in this picture is enjoying playing with a ball of yarn.

ul.li: The first child is an optional <title>.
Next, is one <mediaobject>, <table>, or <code>. Instead of contain one of these, <figure> can contain multiple <subfigure> tags.
The last child is an optional <caption> tag.

body.p: A <title> tag is only used as the first child of a <figure>. It provides a short title for a figure. Its role is distinct from <caption<, which provides a description of the figure and which might be rather lengthy.

ul.li: It has no attributes.

body.p: <title> can only contain plain text .

A subfigure is used inside of a <figure> when you want to use more than one <mediaobject> or <table>, etc. inside of the same <figure>. In fact, the use of <subfigure> is the same as the use of <figure> except that it can not contain <title> or other <subfigure>.

ul.li: It has an optional id attribute.

When using this tag you should set the orient attribute for the <figure> that contains it. The orient attribute can be set to horizontal or vertical depending on which direction you want to layout the subfigures.

body.p: <subfigure> can contain one of mediaobject, table, or code followed by an optional caption.

A <caption> tag is only used to provide a note about a <figure> or a <subfigure>. This would be suitable for printing. <caption> is distinct from <title< in that it provides a, possibly lengthy, description of the figure for the reader's use and not an over all title.

ul.li: It has no attributes.

p.font: Figure 5 The cat displayed in this picture is enjoying playing with a ball of yarn.

body.p: <caption> can contain any plain text, math, and the following tags: cnxn, link, important, and emphasis.
The example tag is used to contain examples. Examples are problems that are worked out in the text.

ul.li: It has a required id attribute.

body.p: <example> can contain plain text, math and any of the following tags: cnxn, link, important, emphasis, para, equation, list, code, figure, table, and exercise.

The table tag is used to create tables. It is designed to be a generalized table. That is, there are not rows and columns. Instead, there are two separate sets of groupings. One set of groups is defined by the <group> tag, which contains <elem> tags or elements. The other set is defined by <category> tags. Both an <elem> and its <category> have a desc attribute with the same value.

ul.li: It has a required id attribute.

It has a required orient attribute. This attribute can take values of horizontal or vertical. Vertical corresponds to the elements with the same category being on top of each other (that is, category become a column). Horizontal corresponds to the elements with the same group being on top of each other (that is, group defines a column).

body.p:
The following table has groups of items that are defined by being a fruit or vegetable and by their color. For example, the first element is a red fruit. Fruit Vegetables Apple Tomato Orange Carrot Grape Lettuce
and it might be rendered like this: FruitVegetables AppleTomato OrangeCarrot GrapeLettuce
<table> contains one <categories> tag followed by one or more <group> tags.
<categories< groups all of the <category> tags together.

ul.li: It has no attributes.

body.p: <categories> must contain one or more <category> tags. The order of the <category> tags with the <categories> tag defines what order they will be displayed in.

Each <category> tag serves to group one set of things. The desc attribute links the category to the element. The content of the <category> will be used as the header for the column or row defined by the category.

ul.li: Must contain a desc attribute. The value of the attribute will be used repeatedly to link the category to specific elements so it should be short.

body.p: It must contain plain text.
The <group> tag pulls together several elements. Those elements are contained within the <group> tag.

ul.li: It has no attributes.

body.p: <group> must contain one or more <elem> tags.

The <elem>, or element, tag contains the actual information of the table. On the one hand it is grouped by the <group> tag. On the other hand it is grouped by the <category> that has the same attribute value for the desc attribute.

ul.li: Must contain a desc attribute. The value of the attribute will be used to link the element to a <category>.
It can contain an optional id attribute.

body.p: <elem> must contain one or more of plain text, math or one of the following tags: cnxn, link, important, emphasis.
